site_title: Australia business investment at 3yr low, outlook tough
content:
Australia business investment at 3yr low, outlook tough

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 01:51 AM

[SYDNEY] Australian business investment fell to a three-year low last quarter as miners retrenched in the face of sliding commodity prices, a black mark for the economy that adds to the case for further cuts in interest rates.

Thursday's figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed investment fell 2.2 per cent to A$37.47 billion (S$39.8 billion) in the fourth quarter of 2014, the lowest result since late 2011.

The Australian dollar slipped 20 ticks to US$0.7860 on the data.

Early spending plans for 2015/16 were also on the weaker side of expectations at A$109 billion, with sectors outside of mining reluctant to invest. "This is a disappointing set of numbers for those looking for a successful growth transition," said Michael Blythe, chief economist at Commonwealth Bank. "This adds to the case for the Reserve Bank to step up to the plate again next week and so I think we'll see a 2 per cent cash rate next Tuesday." The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut rates to a record low of 2.25 per cent earlier this month amid signs the economy was struggling to regain momentum.

Financial markets are fully priced for another move in the next few months, but are divided on whether it will come as soon as the RBA's March 3 policy meeting. Interbank futures imply a 52 per cent probability of an easing next week.

After a decade of massive expansion, mining investment is in retreat as projects reach completion while steep falls in prices for many commodities are forcing companies to cut costs.

Analysts at ANZ estimate annual spending on resource projects could shrink to just A$32 billion in 2017, from A$88 billion in 2014 and A$103 billion the year before.

Policy makers have been hoping other sectors would fill the investment gap, but so far the performance is patchy.

Housing is doing its part as the amount spent on home construction rose 10 per cent over 2104 to a record A$54 billion, while approvals to build new homes are at all-time highs.

Commercial construction has declined with approvals for new work falling sharply in recent months, while public spending on infrastructure will take up some slack but long lead times and political uncertainty make it unreliable. "There's a lack of animal spirits," said JPMorgan chief economist Stephen Roberts, echoing a lament much-voiced by RBA officials. "It certainly adds to the case for another rate cut and we have a move pencilled-in for May."

site_title: A different ballgame for United Envirotech?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A different ballgame for United Envirotech?

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

china everbright water

Follow

NEWS of the intended acquisition of United Envirotech by Chinese conglomerate Citic has created excitement in the company, the market's reason being that United Envirotech stands a chance of joining the league of SIIC Environment Holdings (formerly Asia Water Technology) and China Everbright Water (formerly HanKore Environment Tech Group) - two Singapore-listed wastewater treatment companies with the backing of a Chinese state-owned firm.

Being backed by a state-owned conglomerate offers the opportunity for United Envirotech to penetrate China's burgeoning wastewater treatment sector. And investors hoping for a breakthrough for United Envirotech might be drawing parallels with Shanghai Industrial Holdings' 2010 acquisition of the then beleaguered Asia Water Technology.

But the big question is whether the market's optimism has been misplaced. For the ballgame appears to be different for United Envirotech. And investors holding their breath for history to repeat itself may be in for disappointment.

Citic's conditional offer to acquire over 50 per cent of United Envirotech is due to come 4-6 months after its pre-conditional offer was launched last November. That should be mid-March onwards. With Citic's support, more doors will swing open for United Envirotech to tap the Chinese water sector. It will also enjoy wider, cheaper financing options to expand its business in the capital-intensive wastewater treatment space.

Maybank Kim Eng analyst, Wei Bin, predicts water tariff hikes to be the organic growth driver of China's water sector for the near-term at least. It's a sound call. Based on 2010 data from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), the average water and sewage tariffs in China was US$0.42 per cubic metre, versus the global average of US$1.50-4.30. As China's economy matures, naturally its water tariffs will head north.

Over the next three years, Mr Wei forecasts China's water tariffs to rise 10 per cent year on year and lift the sector's return on equity by 180 basis points, on average, to 8.9 per cent. Still, United Envirotech has the least wastewater treatment capacity among Singapore-listed players. Its current capacity is roughly 1.4 million tonnes per day, versus SIIC's 4.5 million tonnes and Everbright Water's 3.8 million tonnes, Mr Wei's data revealed.

For every 10 per cent increase in water tariffs, he estimates SIIC's and Everbright Water's net profit gain at 11 and 9 per cent respectively, while predicting United Envirotech's net profit to grow just 7 per cent.

United Envirotech traditionally relies more on EPC (engineering, procurement and construction) projects, which offers volatile, one-off returns. Post-acquisition, the company will seek to boost its recurring income base by expanding its wastewater treatment capacity, thus improving overall earnings and returns stability. A way forward is to acquire Chinese water companies, United Envirotech's executive director Chong Weng Chiew told The Business Times.

With Citic's entry, it is natural to expect United Envirotech to follow the path of SIIC, whose revenue since acquisition has multiplied almost five-fold to 286 million yuan (S$61.75 million) as at Dec 31, 2014, mainly through the merger & acquisition (M&A) of Chinese water companies. Since acquisition, SIIC's counter has more than doubled in value to S$0.134.

But United Envirotech is being acquired at an entirely different time. Last November, SIIC's management had announced that there are fewer acquisitions of Chinese water companies with treatment capacity of over one million tonnes per day available than a few years ago. Instead, they guided that it would be more common to acquire companies or projects with treatment capacity of only 0.1-0.3 million tonnes per day in the future. It would henceforth be unrealistic to expect United Envirotech to grow its capacity at the same pace that SIIC did in the past few years.

An alternative method to boost recurring income is for United Envirotech to bid on new government wastewater treatment projects, which will take at least a year or two for the company to turn earnings accretive, Dr Chong said.

Disregarding the past, SIIC still has a headstart to United Envirotech. The former's parent company, Shanghai Industrial Holding, has a joint venture which owns more than five million tonnes per day of water treatment capacity, providing SIIC a possible avenue for fast asset injection.

But United Envirotech is set to be Citic's sole water vehicle. It could thus take a while for United Envirotech to significantly expand its wastewater treatment capacity to further benefit off rising water tariffs.

United Envirotech's valuations are also rich, trading at 31.6 price-earnings ratio, versus SIIC's 21.9, data from the Singapore Exchange shows.

That is not to say that United Envirotech falls short of SIIC and Everbright Water entirely. It does have a stronger foothold in the industrial wastewater treatment space, where fewer merger & acquisitions have occurred. The industrial wastewater treatment sector also holds greater barriers to entry and offers better returns, albeit higher risks, than that of municipal wastewater treatment, in which SIIC and Everbright Water are more active. But if priority is to improve earnings stability, that is best offered by the lower-risk municipal wastewater treatment sector.

While there is no doubt that United Envirotech will benefit off Citic's backing, with SIIC's cheap valuations, following China sovereign wealth fund CIC's exit, and Everbright Water's M&A potential, with its low gearing ratio, cash-rich reserves and having had an M&A dry-spell over the past 12 months, one must be patient enough for United Envirotech's longer-term potential.

site_title: Room for more left-leaning policies in S'pore, but no free-for-all: panel
content:
Room for more left-leaning policies in S'pore, but no free-for-all: panel

Published

Wed, Feb 25, 2015 · 09:50 PM

How countries compare

Singapore

BUDGET 2015 marked yet another step to the left by the government - and it won't be its last, said panellists at the Economic Society of Singapore's (ESS) Budget forum on Wednesday.

Out of the slew of initiatives aimed at strengthening the country's social safety nets, the one which seems to have left the biggest impression is the

Silver Support Scheme

- a permanent initiative which will give quarterly cash payouts of between S$300 and S$750 to the elderly poor, depending on the senior's lifetime wages, household support, and housing type.

Said OCBC economist Selena Ling: "With the Silver Support Scheme, what's interesting this time around is that it's an intergenerational transfer. Unlike the Pioneer Generation Package - where we're talking about a specific slice of Singapore only - now anybody who turns 65, subject to (a few) criteria, will basically automatically qualify."

Indeed, Silver Support is permanent - both for the needy senior's life, and for future generations of elderly poor in Singapore.

This, she said, is "not the traditional model" that the government tends to use - where caveats are aplenty and assistance is temporary. "The Silver Support Scheme is one further step to the left," added Ms Ling.

Giovanni Ko, assistant professor at Nanyang Technological University's (NTU) Division of Economics, also pointed to the fact that the scheme is "conditional on need, not on work".

"Until now, the government has been very much focused on talking about the need for people to be self-sufficient and so on. That's why I think this is quite a big deal. There is a softening of the stance away from a very - I don't want to say harsh - but a very productive kind of welfare system where you get what you put in. (Now, the narrative is along the lines of) let's all help each other, let's take collective responsibility."

So even though he described the amount of cash provided by Silver Support as "not groundbreaking", Dr Ko believes the scheme "says more than it (appears to) at first".

Taken together with Budget 2015's surprise announcement of an increase in the top marginal rate of personal income tax to 22 per cent from 20 per cent, and the larger-than-anticipated S$32.1 billion earmarked for social development - a 16.3 per cent increase over the previous financial year - all panellists at the ESS event agreed that Budget 2015 marked a clearer intent to mitigate inequality.

As for whether the Singapore government will continue to roll out more left-leaning social policies and redistributive measures in the years to come, speakers like Ms Ling and CIMB economist Song Seng Wun certainly think so.

"I think the pace at which they're moving in that direction is still politically acceptable - in fact, it's kind of good timing," said Mr Song. "But more importantly, from an economic standpoint, it is right to do more. I believe a happier middle class is a more productive middle class."

Still, Ms Ling stressed that even as the government ramps up social spending, it will continue to adopt a prudent approach, where targeted help is extended to those most in need. She said: "The government probably has a little bit more of a left tilt to go. But I think the point is really that it's not the traditional welfare model that you see in the West. They've been quite clear, even with the Silver Support Scheme, that it's not a free-for-all. You probably won't (see Singapore) get to the stage where you have unemployment benefits, or (the types of policies) that Western welfare models have."

site_title: Noble says Iceberg author a former staff; group posts US$240m Q4 loss
content:
Noble says Iceberg author a former staff; group posts US$240m Q4 loss

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

noble group

Follow

Noble Group

Singapore

NOBLE Group has fingered a former employee as the person behind Iceberg Research, as it reported on Thursday its first quarterly loss in three years due to a heavy impairment charge on an associate.

The author of the research reports is a "disgruntled" former employee that the group fired 11/2 years ago, Noble chief executive Yusuf Alireza revealed in a briefing call.

"We have a high degree of confidence we know who it is," he said. The company has handed the information over to the regulators and does not intend to take any legal action against the person.

"We don't plan to spend any management time on it or shareholders' resources on it... Our stakeholders will judge us not by an anonymous blogger but by our results, and that's what we want to focus on."

The largest commodities trader in Asia by revenue posted a net quarterly loss of US$240 million - its first since September 2011, against a net profit of US$117 million a year ago. For the three months ended Dec 31, revenue dropped 14 per cent to US$21 billion.

For the full year, net profit almost halved to US$132 million, missing by far the average estimate of US$470.6 million by 13 analysts, according to Bloomberg data. Revenue was 4 per cent higher at US$85.8 billion.

Notwithstanding these, "2014 was a landmark year for us", said Mr Alireza, pointing to how the sale of Noble Agri had freed up its balance sheet, and "breakthroughs" in performance and market penetration, in particular by its oil liquids and power businesses in the US.

The group said that it had written off US$438 million for the year, including a US$200 million charge for Yancoal Australia, the valuation for which had been criticised by Iceberg Research.

The little-known research firm had earlier questioned Noble's accounting treatment of certain subsidiaries and said that the group overstated the value of Yancoal - the Australia-listed coal miner in which Noble has a 13 per cent stake - by US$603 million.

Noble, however, said that its latest results had not been affected "in any way" by the Iceberg report. The group reviews the value of its associates and investments on a quarterly basis, and on a more detailed level annually.

It arrived at the value for Yancoal based on a cash flow model that has been verified by both internal control functions and its auditor EY, and used conservative assumptions around input variables such as production levels, fuel inputs and coal prices.

The model provides for a range of values, and "we have impaired Yancoal right below the bottom of that range", said Mr Alireza, who also called Iceberg's suggestion of using the market capitalisation of Yancoal as its value "naive".

Both its board and auditor are comfortable with the adjustments in value, he added.

Noble's shares have fallen 12 per cent since Iceberg published its first report on Feb 15. Its website does not provide any contact details nor other identifying information.

In its second report on Thursday, Iceberg pointed to a "divergence" between Noble's net profit and operating cash flow as a result of Noble overstating the fair value of its long-term contracts.

Noble has a practice of booking the entire profit for long-term unrealised contracts the same day they are signed, said Iceberg. It also suggested that Noble had manipulated projections for forward prices and tonnage to inflate the fair values of these contracts. "These contracts surged from near zero in 2009 to an unprecedented net US$3.8 billion," it said in a 28-page report released before Noble announced its results. Impairing these values would "dramatically impact" Noble's financial performance.

Iceberg further accused Noble of stretching accounting rules "to the maximum", though it said that there was no outright accounting fraud.

Noble rejected these claims of inflated unrealised contract values as "factually incorrect". Iceberg had ignored the fair value of inventory, and the effect of short-term rolling hedging versus the long-term physical contracts, it said.

The group has a consistent mark to market - or the practice in measuring the fair value of its contracts - policy, Mr Alireza emphasised. "This is our core business."

As part of the asset-light strategy that the group is pursuing, its business model relies on the group's ability to manage market, credit and operational risks for buyers and sellers. The group manages 12,000 contracts with a weighted average duration of five years.

These are marked to market in order to provide profit and loss figures daily, said Mr Alireza. "It's a function of risk management."

Iceberg Research is expected to release a third report that will focus on Noble's debt levels and its investment grade credit rating. Noble's shares, which were suspended on Thursday morning following the second attack by Iceberg, will resume trading on Friday.

site_title: S'pore and Hong Kong must both prepare for the next lap
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore and Hong Kong must both prepare for the next lap

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Singapore

THE changes are palpable. The rapid pace of growth in Singapore is something evident to anyone who has visited the city. A port, a mega city, a financial services hub and a free economy. Singapore also happens to share these titles with another rapidly growing city, Hong Kong. Cities that are similar in a myriad ways, yet so uniquely different. Twin cities and arch rivals.

Hong Kong's greatest strength is its role as a connector between China and the rest of the world - something that HK CEO CY Leung has always believed in. More than 30 per cent of Hong Kong's inward-bound foreign direct investment comes from China. Add to that the recently established Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect and you have a city with a special place with regard to the Asian giant.

What Hong Kong is to China, Singapore is to the Asean region and India. Singapore's strategic location as a port, with a sound political system and strong legal framework make it a choice destination for foreign investment. With a double taxation avoidance agreement with India, Singapore sees a great deal of investment from India. According to the Indian High Commission here, about 28 per cent of India's trade with Asean came from Singapore in 2012-2013, making it India's largest trade and investment partner from Asean.

Singapore's position as an important port and maritime centre is another reason for its popularity. Hong Kong, however, in recent times has seen a drop in its ranking as more ports develop in southern China. From being among the three busiest ports in the world, it is now in fourth place, according to Forbes.

Hong Kong has also seen its share of political upheavals lately. If proximity to China is its biggest trump card, it could also take a direct hit if there are changes in Chinese policy. But while China's economic slowdown has economists concerned, they are also certain the drop isn't severe enough to be a reason for worry.

JPMorgan's chief market strategist for Asia, Tai Hui, based in Hong Kong, says that both Singapore and Hong Kong have their own niches. "Both cities have a clientele in financial services. Hong Kong has an advantage with China, while Singapore caters more to the Asean markets. So the clientele doesn't really overlap. They have their own niches, and there's definitely enough space for two."

Yet, as they grow, both need to turn inward and dig deeper into what could give them the leading edge. Infosys founder Narayana Murthy says both of them have the potential to become technology hubs of the future.

site_title: The latest investment theme in Toronto is rental apartments
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The latest investment theme in Toronto is rental apartments

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Toronto

THE dreary six-storey apartment block in Toronto's north end was nicknamed "Divorcee Towers" after the newly single who lodged at its short-stay units. Then Timbercreek Asset Management Inc moved in.

The real estate investment company installed new hardwood floors, stainless steel appliances, energy efficient windows and preserved 1930s art-deco details such as a steel-cage elevator, boosting the rent to about the same as a modern downtown condominium.

Timbercreek is at the forefront of the next boom in Toronto's supercharged housing market: rental apartments. While the company specialises in renovating dilapidated buildings, at least 21 high-rise projects are slated to be built by developers as rental apartments in the city.

Meanwhile, apartment real estate investment trusts are the best performing Reits on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

"There's a huge demand for rental," Ugo Bizzarri at Timbercreek, said. "We are seeing for the first time in 40 years people are starting to build rental."

Demand is growing for leased space as house prices surge out of reach for many, the condo market cools and investors seek stable returns in a low-interest rate world.

Timbercreek is raising about C$200 million (S$218 million) for its fourth and largest real estate investment fund, which it will use to buy and renovate up to 20 buildings in Canada and then sell to pension funds.

The first Timbercreek Opportunity Fund, which invested in 766 apartment units worth C$76 million, had an internal rate of return of 20 per cent, according to the company. Its latest offering, the third Timbercreek Opportunity Fund, was started in April 2011 and has purchased 1,986 units valued at C$186 million spread across major Canadian cities.

Other rental companies are also reaping the rewards of rising rental demand. Shares of Canadian Apartment Properties Reit, the country's largest apartment Reit by units, are up 13 per cent this year, the best-performer on the Standard & Poor's/TSX Capped Reit Index.

The Toronto-based Reit is set to gain from "improving economic growth in Ontario, easing of migration outflows as Alberta's growth slows and an apartment market that remains supply constrained", Heather Kirk at Bank of Montreal said in a research note. Fourth-quarter rents for the firm rose in all major cities, according to financial documents.

There are 21 large rental projects under construction or in a planning phase in Toronto and its nearby regions, according to data compiled by Urbanation Inc. If completed, that would be the most erected in a decade, surpassing the 12 built in 2012, according to Canada Mortgage & Housing Corp.

While a flood of new condos leased out by investors has helped fill demand for rental units, vacancy was 1.6 per cent last year and has held under 2 per cent since 2010, suggesting supply isn't catching up fast enough.

Projects in the works now range in size and location from the 23 storey "66 Isabella" downtown with its own theatre and rooftop lounge to a two-tower complex replacing aged townhouses with about 520 rental units midtown.

Home prices in Toronto have surged 60 per cent from 2006 and gained 7 per cent to an average C$581,000 last year alone, according to the Canadian Real Estate Association, prompting people to hunt for cheaper alternatives. The average monthly rent for a one-bedroom apartment unit rose 17 per cent to C$1,609 over the same period.

"Affordability is a big reason" for rising rental demand, said Sam Crignano, president of Cityzen Development Group. "A lot of young people starting out don't have the down payment and so their only option is to rent."

Mr Crignano is benefiting from investor demand. The developer was preparing to build The Selby, a 49-storey red brick and glass condo tower, with Stephen Diamond, chief executive officer of Diamond Corp, up until last year.

Real estate agents sold 210 units worth C$80 million, according to Insider Condo Club, the marketing firm that ran the sales event on Nov 15. It took just three hours to sell the units at a packed red-carpet event.

A week later, Mr Crignano and Mr Diamond agreed to sell the site to an institutional investor who's planning to build it as a rental instead.

"We're probably going to do more of these," said Mr Crignano, whose latest condo project is the 58-floor L-shaped tower designed by architect Daniel Libeskind. "As long as conditions remain the way they are, institutions will continue seeking out these types of investments."

Another reason companies are building rental towers is it's faster and more profitable as the condo market cools, Mr Diamond said. It's taking longer to offload hundreds of units and it's more difficult to secure financing to start building.

And the city's developers can't raise condo prices like they used to. Prices for new high-rise units have levelled off since their 2011 peak, according to data compiled by RealNet Canada Inc. High-rise prices gained about 4 per cent to C$450,014 at the end of September 2014 from the prior year, the data show.

"Condo development is still cyclical and we're coming from an environment where you announced the project and you sold it out in two days and you just built it out," Corrado Russo at Timbercreek said last month. "We were going a little too fast and now this is a healthy pause to try and let the market catch up." BLOOMBERG

site_title: Billionaire's Moscow office block is two-thirds empty
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Billionaire's Moscow office block is two-thirds empty

The Roman Abramovich-owned complex, like others, has been hit by economy's slump

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Roman Abramovich

Follow

Moscow

BILLIONAIRE Roman Abramovich's White Gardens office complex in Moscow stands about two-thirds empty as a supply glut and the sinking Russian economy make it difficult for landlords to find new tenants.

The Russian owner of London's Chelsea Football Club bought the business centre near the central Tverskaya Street in November 2013.

Since then, he's secured new leases accounting for less than 10 per cent of the property's 63,000 square metres of space, according to his spokesman, John Mann. About a third of the property, opened in 2013, is occupied, he added.

"We are taking a long-term view by making sure we have a good client base and by not diminishing its value," Mr Mann said. "We have a class-A, top-notch asset."

Office demand in Moscow slumped at the end of last year as a drop in oil prices, a tumbling rouble and economic sanctions levelled against Russia discouraged companies from expanding in the city.

The average vacancy rate for the highest-quality office space in the city climbed to 29 per cent at the end of 2014 from 18 per cent a year earlier as new properties added to supply, Jones Lang LaSalle Inc (JLL) said in a report.

Mr Abramovich acquired White Gardens from VTB Capital, TPG Capital LLP and the sovereign-wealth fund China Investment Corporation.

The complex, which consists of two buildings connected by an open-air arcade with terraces and rooftop gardens, has won design and environmental awards.

Almost half of the retail space in the atrium remains closed. The Cheapside Josper Bistro, named after a street in the City of London financial district, was the busiest place at lunchtime on a Friday this month, with about half of the tables occupied by office workers enjoying burgers and beers.

The adjoining Box Bar and the newly-opened Trattoria Siciliana were almost empty.

"It's bit of a ghost town here," Kamil Anderzhanov, a risk analyst at Deloitte, said over a coffee in Cheapside. "I don't think workers in the surrounding area realise this complex is even open."

Owners of properties coming onto the market recently face greater challenges than those who secured new tenants before last year.

Moscow City, a collection of newly built towers located three kilometres west of the Kremlin, has a vacancy rate of about 45 per cent, according to Tom Mundy, head of research for Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States at JLL.

The White Square development directly to the south of Mr Abramovich's complex opened in 2009 as the first phase of the White District office area.

The properties are almost full after signing up long-term tenants including JPMorgan Chase & Co, PricewaterhouseCoopers, Deloitte and McKinsey & Co. It was sold to Russian real estate company O1 Properties for US$1 billion in 2013.

Restaurants on the ground floor, including steakhouse Torro Grill and the Italian Osteria della Piazza Bianca, were buzzing with large groups of bankers and consultants last Friday.

Mr Abramovich has achieved 100 per cent occupancy at his other premium office blocks at Krylatsky Hills and Baltschug Plaza in the city centre, according to Mr Mann. Both were completed in 2004. The 48-year-old is the world's 90th richest person with a US$12.7 billion fortune, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

The vacancy rate has been climbing in Moscow's office market as projects that were started while Russia's economy was growing deliver new stock.

Space in the capital grew by 1.4 million square metres last year and it's anticipated to climb to 18 million square metres by the end of 2015 as skyscrapers open in the Moscow City district, according to JLL. A record amount of top-tier space was completed last year, the US broker said.

"A lot of stock was coming on to market and vacancy rates were ticking up as the economy slowed even before Putin unexpectedly annexed Crimea," JLL's Mr Mundy said. "Rents fell 20 per cent last year and will drop by another 15 per cent this year, but we see things levelling off by the middle of the year."

Retail landlords across Moscow are feeling the pinch too, with rents falling last year by 25 per cent in the most sought-after space locations and by 30 per cent for second-tier areas, JLL said in a report on Tuesday.

Russia's economy is set for a 5.6 per cent contraction this year and it probably won't repeat the rapid rebound that the country experienced in 2009, "particularly given the rising risk of further sanctions", Morgan Stanley economist Alina Slyusarchuk said in a note in January.

While Mr Abramovich's White Gardens has secured tenants including Microsoft Corp, private-equity investor Baring Vostok and law firms Dentons and Baker & McKenzie LLP, it's not enough to dispel the sense of emptiness.

"It's one of the most luxurious business class offices but it's empty, with only three floors taken in our building," said Irina Buyanivna, a legal assistant at Dentons, whose firm moved to White Gardens a year ago. "The main problem for us is the lack of a canteen, but the are lots of places around here to eat." BLOOMBERG

site_title: More pay for hourly-wage workers in US
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More pay for hourly-wage workers in US

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Walmart

Follow

New York

FOR Anthony Rodriguez, every diaper for his two-year-old son means less money to put food on the table, or to fill up his car at the petrol station.

Mr Rodriguez, 26, makes those trade-offs even though he already receives above-minimum wages at Wal-Mart, and will make at least US$10 an hour next year, part of a move by Wal-Mart to raise wages for hundreds of thousands of workers.

"It's not going to help us. We need the hours," said Mr Rodriguez, a member of the union-supported workers' group, OUR Walmart.

He says that he constantly begs his managers for full-time work at the bustling Wal-Mart superstore in Rosemead, California, but is assigned as little as 18 hours a week. "I work as hard as I can, and when they offer me hours, I stay," he said. "But when the time comes, and I beg them for hours because I'm not going to afford rent, they don't want to help me."

The move to increase hourly wages by Wal-Mart, which employs 1.3 million workers as the country's largest private sector employer, is sending ripples through the retail industry. On Wednesday, the TJX Cos, which runs the discount chain TJ Maxx, said that it would follow suit, raising the pay of its hourly wage workers to at least US$9 later this year, and to US$10 next year.

With some progress on the hourly wage front, labour activists are highlighting another long-standing demand: more hours - and more consistent hours - for hourly-wage workers like Mr Rodriguez, something that they say will make as much a difference to workers' pocketbooks as an increase in wages.

Wal-Mart says that about half of its hourly-wage workers work part time, and that percentage can be even higher at other retailers. Stores change many of their workers' schedules week to week. And while many people prefer to work part time - for instance, college students eager for extra spending money - the number of part-timers who would prefer to work full time is surging, especially in the retailing and hospitality industries.

"Wages are just the first step in getting Wal-Mart on the road toward being the type of employer that treats its employees with respect, and part of that is to set some standards around hours and work schedules," said Rashad Robinson, executive director of ColorOfChange, an online civil rights organisation that has campaigned for Wal-Mart to raise wages and give workers better hours.

"It's about creating an environment where employees are not just at the whim of Wal-Mart," he said.

At the heart of demands for higher wages and better hours, experts say, is the dwindling number of middle-class jobs. More primary wage earners who in the past may have held stable blue-collar jobs in manufacturing are now relying on low-wage jobs at Wal-Mart or other discount retailers to support their families.

Mr Rodriguez, who works at Wal-Mart assembling bikes and barbecue sets, supports his fiancée on an income that can be as little as US$900 a month. After spending about US$550 on rent, US$65 on petrol, as well as paying for food, diapers, mobile phone costs and insurance, he can rarely afford new clothes or recreation, and when hours are especially scarce, he borrows money from his sister. He is looking for a second job to supplement his income, most likely a graveyard shift as a security guard. He is already US$4,000 in debt.

At the same time, Wal-Mart and other retailers, facing stiff competition and shrinking margins, have taken a more severe approach to controlling labour costs, doing more to align staffing to customer traffic. Sometimes that involves sophisticated software that tracks the flow of customers and allows managers to assign just enough employees to handle the anticipated demand.

By hiring a large pool of hourly workers whose hours can expand or contract depending on business need, retailers can better sync hours to demand, experts say; posting schedules with limited advance notice allows managers to further minimise the risk of assigning too many hours. Restricting work hours also limits outlays on overtime and employee benefits.

"A number of companies have become more focused on keeping a very tight link between variations in consumer demand and the number of staffing hours," said Susan Lambert, an employment expert at the University of Chicago. "It's easier to do that if you have a lot of people who can be scheduled for very short shifts, and who are hungry for hours." She added, "But that makes it harder, harder and harder for these workers to move up the ladder in terms of wage growth." Wal-Mart has said that on top of raising wages, it will work to give some employees more control over their schedules.

Kory Lundberg, a company spokesman, said, "We're pursuing comprehensive changes to our hiring, training, compensation and scheduling programs." "The company is creating clearer career paths for associates so they know what is expected of them in order to move from entry-level positions to jobs with more responsibility, including full-time positions," he said. site_title: GM, Toyota take top spots in US study
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

GM, Toyota take top spots in US study

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Toyota

Follow

Southfield, Michigan

General Motors showed gains in quality as its Buick brand passed Toyota and the two automakers tied for the most top ratings in J D Power's latest US vehicle dependability study.

GM and Toyota each took first place in seven of the 19 car or truck categories in the study, which measures problems reported by owners after three years.

Toyota's Lexus luxury brand was rated best overall for the fourth straight year, with 89 problems per 100 vehicles, followed by Buick at 110 and the Toyota brand at 111.

The study, an industry benchmark released on Wednesday, also found that owners are having issues with connected-car technology such as Bluetooth which let drivers make hands-free calls, and voice recognition systems. Those were the two top problems reported by owners.

"Vehicle owner expectations of advanced technology capabilities are growing," said Renee Stephens at J D Power. "Owners clearly want the latest technology in their vehicles, and they don't hesitate to express their disapproval when it doesn't work."

The two connectivity issues were also the most often cited in J D Power's 2014 initial quality study, which is based on reports after the first 90 days of ownership.

Jeff Wrona, GM's executive director for vehicle engineering and powertrain quality, said it equips dealers to address technology issues at the point of sale and beyond. "We have 50 connected customer specialists across the US," he said. "These are people who are specifically trained on infotainment systems, and they support and train the dealers."

Sam Butto, a Toyota spokesman, said the company wasn't disappointed by the results of the J D Power study. "When we see the rest of the industry doing well, that's good for everybody," he said.

GM's Cadillac ranked fourth with 114 problems per 100 vehicles, as all four of the company's brands were in the top 10, including ties. Toyota's third brand, Scion, also made it into the top 10. Honda Motor Co's namesake brand was fifth at 116. The score for Nissan's main brand was 128.

The industry average was 147. Because the study was redesigned for 2015, the scores aren't comparable to those from previous years.

Ford Motor Co's namesake brand was below the industry average, at 188, while its Lincoln was seventh with 118. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles' Chrysler brand was at 173, and the company's only marque above the average was Ram, at 134.

The study is based on responses from more than 34,000 original owners of 2012-model vehicles, J D Power said. BLOOMBERG

site_title: Aussie, NZ dollars move in opposite directions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Aussie, NZ dollars move in opposite directions

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

London

THE Australian and New Zealand dollars were the main movers among major currencies on Thursday, pushed in opposite directions by contrasting signals on the health of two struggling economies.

Two days of testimony from US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen have done little to resolve the debate over when US interest rates will rise - although if anything, expectations have been prodded back to later in the second half of this year.

The Aussie fell as much as half a per cent against the US dollar, the euro and yen before recovering some poise early in Europe, after unexpectedly weak business investment numbers in an economy struggling for growth.

The kiwi dollar by contrast gained 0.4 per cent against both the US dollar and yen after data showed a surprise surplus on trade. "In Australia, people knew the mining numbers would be weak but were expecting construction investment to make up for that. When it didn't, we saw the reaction on the (Aussie) dollar," said Adam Myers, European head of FX strategy at Credit Agricole in London.

The Aussie recovered quickly, however, and Mr Myers said that forward interest rates had not moved to price in any more likelihood of a cut in borrowing costs by the Reserve Bank to follow the reduction at its meeting earlier this month. "They've done one, they will not do another immediately, it will be wait and see for a little bit, then they'll go again," said Mr Myers. "So the market had got a bit ahead of itself."

The US dollar was bang in the middle of ranges that it has held for respectively four weeks and three months against the euro and yen, frustrating the bulk of investors who - positioning data shows - are betting on further gains for the greenback. "Janet Yellen has done a fair bit in recent days both to help stop the (US) dollar's advance and to suck volatility out of the FX market," said Kit Juckes, a strategist with French bank Societe Generale in London.

The next obvious cue is US consumer prices data due at 1330 GMT. The euro was marginally lower at US$1.1353. The US dollar inched down to 118.73 yen. "If we get a surprise on CPI (consumer price index), if the core is lower for example, then the euro is going to go higher," said Mr Myers. "There are a lot of people who have been short (of euros) for a while and are just going 'come on, come on'. A move higher on the euro, and you will see more of them close out." REUTERS

content:

QAF full-year profit up 49% to S$45.1m

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

QAF Limited

Singapore

A SIGNIFICANT improvement in its pork business meant that QAF Limited reported a net profit of S$45.1 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2014, up 49 per cent from S$30.2 million in 2013. Revenue was flat at S$1.02 billion. The company did not report a separate breakdown of its fourth-quarter results.

Higher net profit in 2014 was due to lower feed costs for the pork business as well as lower staff, depreciation and utilities costs.

QAF, which is also known for its Gardenia and Bonjour brands of bread, guided for a "comparable or a better level of profitability" for its first quarter ending March 31, 2015.

For 2015, QAF expects its main bakery business and its pork business to "achieve sales increases in terms of their respective domestic currencies in the markets that they operate". Sales in other business segments are also expected to be satisfactory.

QAF declared a final dividend of four Singapore cents a share, unchanged from a year ago. Total dividend for the year was five cents, unchanged from a year ago.

Subsidiary Rivalea, a pork production business in Australia that includes feed milling, farming and production, meat cutting and deboning, and distribution, reported segmental results of S$10.2 million in 2014, from S$2.3 million in 2013.

This was due to higher selling prices, productivity gains and lower material costs. Segmental revenue was down 5 per cent to S$401.7 million due to the weakening of the Australian dollar against the Singapore dollar, but was slightly higher in Australian dollar terms.

QAF's main bakery segment reported segmental results of S$54 million, up 4 per cent, on segmental revenue of S$510.7 million, up 3 per cent. QAF said increased revenue was due to new products, higher production capacities, increased market share and higher selling prices. Profitability improved due to higher sales, efficiencies and economies of scale.

However, QAF's new bakery operations in Fujian, China, incurred losses due to start-up and market development costs.

Meanwhile, the company's trading and logistics segment reported improved results due to higher sales from its wholesale and trading company Ben Foods, and increased rental income from providing cold storage services. QAF's investments segment reported higher profit due to a sale of a non-core dairy business in Australia.

Net asset value per share at end-2014 was 74.7 cents, up from 72.6 cents at end-2013.

QAF ended trading on Thursday at S$1.04, up half a cent, before the results were released.

site_title: Thai artist to hold solo show
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Thai artist to hold solo show

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

HE starts with sketching the main characters on a canvas and from there, Thai artist Knakorn Kachacheewa takes his time to infuse his paintings with the daily experiences and thoughts which inspire him.

Kachacheewa, 46, a lecturer of art at King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, in Bangkok, will be holding his first solo exhibition in Singapore in March entitled The Jungle of Form, Colour and Tempo.

The paintings bear a similarity to those of French painter Henri Rousseau and the title seems to refer to one of Rousseau's famous works -Tropical Forest with Monkeys, where the artist imagined the wildlife in rainforests.

Form, style, colour and aesthetic qualities are emphasised in this series of works, which focuses entirely on painting, says the artist who initially practised printmaking. The central focus is the composition of human, animal, scenery and foliage. "I start with sketches first, collected over time," he says, through an interpreter in a phone interview.

After making his key sketches, Kachacheewa then takes his time to find the imagery to fill in the sketches. "I sketch because I like its line and I keep those sketches because I may use them sometimes. In a short while, I realise that there are stories in those lines and sketches; probably it could be called a process or thinking method," he says.

The main figures are humans and animals, and their stories are very much inspired by his personal experiences and the situations that he encountered.

He believes that the Singapore audience will be able to relate to his paintings, as he tries to capture the emotions of sadness or happiness. "I think it's the daily things that touch people, rather than politics or big events."

As for style, his technique focuses on light and shadows, he explains, which is a very Western concept. He notes that Thai art has long had a tradition of two dimensional depictions where primary elements are kept isolated. Kachacheewa's composition has been described as a blend of East and West. His characters have a surreal quality but they remain real enough to relate to.

"The Jungle of Form, Colour and Tempo of Knakorn Kachacheewa" will run from March 5-26 on the fourth floor of Raffles City Convention Centre, foyer area.

site_title: Q4 UK business investment slips as oil prices fall; GDP growth steady at 0.5%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Q4 UK business investment slips as oil prices fall; GDP growth steady at 0.5%

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

britain

Follow

London

INVESTMENT by businesses in Britain fell at its sharpest rate in nearly six years in the last quarter of 2014, hit by lower investment in the petroleum sector as global oil prices fell.

As estimated in a preliminary reading, British gross domestic product (GDP) between October and December grew by a quarterly 0.5 per cent, slowing from 0.7 per cent in the third quarter, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said on Thursday.

That was the slowest quarterly growth rate in a year.

In year-on-year terms, growth was 2.7 per cent, also unchanged from last month's preliminary estimate by the ONS.

Business investment fell 1.4 per cent in the fourth quarter from the previous three-month period after a 1.2 per cent fall in the third quarter.

"Given the recent steep fall in oil prices, it might be expected that investment by the oil extraction industry might also fall, as oil production becomes less profitable," the ONS said in a news release.

The quarterly fall in investment was the biggest drop since the second quarter of 2009 and contrasted with a forecast for an increase of 1.9 per cent in a Reuters poll.

Economists have said business investment in Britain might also be affected by uncertainty over the outcome of Britain's upcoming national elections in May.

The Bank of England (BOE) forecast earlier this month that Britain's economy will grow 2.9 per cent this year - its fastest growth in nearly a decade - as the plunge in oil prices puts more money in the pockets of consumers and businesses.

Household spending, which accounts for nearly two-thirds of Britain's economic expenditure, grew a quarterly 0.5 per cent in the October-December period, slowing from 0.7 per cent in Q3.

Spending by households in yearly terms rose 2.2 per cent - its fastest pace since early 2008 - before the financial crisis began to hit Britain's economy.

Britain's dominant services industry remained the big driver of growth, rising 0.8 per cent in the quarter and 3.3 per cent in yearly terms, its strongest year-on-year growth since the end of 2007.

Industrial output rose 0.1 per cent, revised up from an original estimate that the sector contracted slightly in the quarter due to weak power generation. But construction shrank by more than first thought.

Net trade gave a boost to GDP too, contributing 0.6 percentage point to the quarterly growth rate, a rare encouraging sign for Britain's attempts to rely less on domestic demand.

The slowdown in growth at the end of last year has not prevented Prime Minister David Cameron from putting the economy front and centre in the campaigning by his Conservative Party ahead of national elections on May 7.

Britain's economic growth of 2.6 per cent in 2014 as a whole was the fastest in seven years.

Private sector readings of the economy in the first two months of 2015 suggest the year got off to a strong start.

Britain's economic output is now 3.4 per cent bigger than its previous peak before the financial crisis in early 2008 and is about 8 per cent bigger than at the time of the last elections in May 2010. REUTERS

Flooding, commodity rout slash Sime Darby Q2 earnings by 47%

Published

Sime Darby

Follow

Kuala Lumpur

MALAYSIA'S Sime Darby, the world's biggest listed palm oil producer, said second-quarter net profit slid 47 per cent, hit by a commodities rout, flooding and an oversupply of competing oilseeds.

Malaysian palm oil prices, which set the tone for global prices, fell 9 per cent in the October-December period from a year earlier, the worst quarter in two years. Over 2014, they fell 15 per cent. "The sharp decline in crude oil prices and slowdown in global economic growth have exacerbated the need to push for greater productivity and cost efficiency," Chief Executive Mohd Bakke Salleh said in a statement.

Net profit declined to RM437.4 million (S$165.28 million). Revenue, however, inched up 0.3 per cent to RM10.74 billion.

Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm grower, saw its overall palm production fall 22 per cent in December alone due to the flooding. Sime Darby said that the heavy rain and severe floods were responsible for its fresh fruit bunch yields dropping 12 per cent in quarter.

The company last month won the approval from the European Commission to buy New Britain Palm Oil for US$1.74 billion, which would give Sime significant and high-yielding land holdings in Papua New Guinea.

Mr Bakke said that the proposed takeover is "progressing well" and that Sime looks forward to completing the deal by the end of this quarter.

The benchmark May contract on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange was trading at RM2,270 per tonne on Thursday. Prices have gained nearly 6 per cent in February but are flat for the year so far. Shares of Sime Darby fell 1.37 per cent to RM9.37. The stock has climbed 3.3 per cent year to date, in line with the the benchmark stock index. REUTERS

site_title: Creating a great place to work, grow
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Creating a great place to work, grow

This year's Aon Hewitt Best Employers awards see a new category for SMEs.

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Best Employers in Singapore 2015

BONUS payouts and salaries have never been factors that Aon Hewitt considered explicitly in picking winners for its Best Employers award, which is handed out every two years. So the best employers in the human resources consultancy firm's reckoning are not necessarily generous paymasters.

Yet there are payouts aplenty for those on the payrolls of Aon Hewitt's Best Employers in terms of a great place to work and grow. They get to enjoy what they are doing and can look forward to better prospects in climbing the corporate ladder.

When a company makes more money, employees can enjoy bigger bonuses and salaries every year. But these bonuses and pay hikes will eventually be capped by the employees' job scopes and skills. To earn even more, employees need to learn new skills and get promoted.

Best Employers winners offer employees an opportunity to upgrade and scale new corporate heights.

McDonald's Singapore, this year's top winner, offers not just a fun and caring work place for its crew. The fast-food chain also grooms and put them through formal learning schemes so that they can move on to jobs with bigger responsibilities and higher pay in the company.

And McDonald's, recipient of the Best of the Best award, makes it a point to ensure that there are openings for its employees, in both its local and overseas restaurants.

Hilti Asia Pacific, a provider of leading-edge technology to the global construction industry that is a four-time Best Employers winner, displays a similar passion for people development. Four in five of the company's management openings are filled internally; it hires externally for only one-fifth of its vacancies.

It is a win-win situation. Happy workers make for good business. They are loyal and go the extra mile for the company. They make the company a choice employer, which will be a big draw for new workers at a time of labour scarcity.

Thus, while a bigger number of the Best Employers (when compared with others) put people issues first, Best Employers also have higher profits - nearly a third higher than the market average, according to Aon Hewitt's study.

Best Employers also experience 25 per cent less job-hopping. Almost nine in 10 of their staff would recommend others to work in the company, against 63 per cent for non-Best Employers. Over three-quarters of Best Employers' workers believe that their bosses deliver on their promises, against 56 per cent for other employees.

Nearly four in five of their employees believe their senior management when they say that their employees are the company's most valuable assets; only two in three of non-Best Employers' staff believe that.

Best Employers' focus on people is reflected in a "significantly" higher score on employee engagement, 80 per cent versus 59 per cent for non-Best Employers.

Every one of the Best Employers integrate their high potential programme into their talent management processes, compared with 60 per cent for others.

This year, 12 winners clinched the Best Employers award, including newcomer Goodrich Global, a dealer in interior wall-coverings, which received the Special Recognition SME award - a new category dedicated to small and medium-sized enterprises.

Roche Diagnostics Singapore & Regional HQ, which was not on last year's Best Employers list, won a Special Recognition award for Commitment to Engagement. Another new Best Employer is Hongkong Land, a property developer based in Hong Kong.

Last year's Best of the Best winner, The Ritz Carlton, Millenia Singapore, received the Best Employers award for Hotels in 2015. Holiday Inn Singapore Atrium, the 2014 Best Employer for Hotels, was presented with the Special Recognition award for Generation Y this year.

The Best Employers award was established by Aon Hewitt in 2001 as an exercise in discovering how to create a competitive advantage through people, and exploring what goes into making a workplace of choice.

content:
KPMG finds offer to take Keppel Land private 'not fair but reasonable'

Mindy Tan

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 12:10 PM

KPMG

Follow

Independent financial adviser KPMG Corporate Finance has found the offer by Keppel Corp to take its real estate subsidiary, Keppel Land, private to be not fair but reasonable.

KPMG noted that based on its sum-of-the-parts (SOTP) valuation, the base price and higher offer price are at a "significant discount to the sum-of-the-parts estimated valuation range of between $6.58 and $6.79 per share".

However, the independent financial adviser qualified that the revaluation of properties, which forms a large part of the SOTP surplus value, has been done on an 'as is' basis which assumes that the properties will be disposed of at the assessed values and, accordingly, has not considered any potential development profits should the properties be developed and completed.

On the other hand, the offer can be deemed reasonable for a number of reasons including the fact that the base offer price and higher offer price represent significant premiums to the median share price; that Keppel Corp already owns and controls more than 50 per cent of the total issued share meaning that it is unlikely that there will be another bidder offering better terms in the near term; and that the key valuation metrics compare favourably to the listed median of Keppel Land's listed peers and to the median of precedent transactions involving Singapore property developers.

Keppel Corp on Jan 23 launched an offer to take its real estate subsidiary, Keppel Land, private at a base offer price of S$4.38 per share. This will be raised to S$4.60 per share if acceptance levels exceed the 90 per cent threshold that turns the offer into a compulsory acquisition.

SUBSCRIBERS

A great place for working and healing (Amended)

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

FOUR years ago, Tan Tock Seng Hospital kicked off a "value-based" journey to make TTSH, as the hospital is called in short, "a great place for working, healing, learning and becoming the best".

Winning Aon Hewitt's Best Employers award for a second time is an indication that it is making progress and moving in the right direction, says Eugene Soh, the CEO of Tan Tock Seng Hospital.

The move, made after consulting staff and patients on what they value, was in response to global and national challenges that include an ageing population, integrating healthcare services and, most importantly, the need to build great healthcare teams.

"As we consolidate and take stock, we will continue our journey to further engage our staff on how the work they do can fulfil their aspirations and make their work meaningful," Dr Soh says.

Engagement is a key to producing the "better people" needed to deliver the "better service", TTSH says in a submission for the Best Employers award. Among the hospital's engagement initiatives is one which encourages and makes it easy for staff to engage in value conversations at all levels.

Senior leaders, managers and supervisors are taught skills to engage their staff. TTSH also provides a guidebook offering tips to deepen understanding and practice of staff engagement.

The hospital, which has more than 7,000 staff on its payroll, anchors its people strategy on three key initiatives: A nursing-shared governance model for collaborative decision-making; a patient associate framework; and "creatively inclusive" health and well-being schemes.

Under the first initiative, nurses are given a say through their elected council members in policy recommendations and decisions on issues affecting nursing practice, education, quality and research and work-life governance.

The patient service associates play an important role in patient care by assisting the medical staff with operational procedures and are key to delivering prompt and excellent frontline services to patients."

The "creatively inclusive" health and well-being programmes present to staff a range of work-life balance initiatives and workplace health promotion schemes.

The earlier version of the story quoted Tan Tock Seng Hospital and reported it has 8,000 staff on its payroll. The hospital has clarified that is has more than 7,000. This is in paragraph 7 which has the updated figure. We have also changed the second last paragraph as requested by the hospital for greater clarity.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

AIA Singapore posts 22% rise in new premiums in 2014

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Singapore

AIA Singapore, a subsidiary of Asia's third-largest life insurer group by market value, posted a strong set of full-year financial results.

The insurer on Thursday said it recorded a 22 per cent rise in annualised new premiums - a measure of new policy sales - in 2014 to US$489 million, led by the increased uptake of protection, long-term savings and legacy plans.

Lower sales of the HealthShield plan were offset by strong growth in unit-linked and participating business and this "more balanced mix of savings and protection business" lifted the annualised new premiums, it said.

The value of new business, a measure of future profitability of new policies, climbed 11 per cent on a year- on-year basis to US$299 million in 2014, on the back of sustained growth from prior years.

New business margin, or the value of new business as a percentage of annualised new premiums, slid 6.1 percentage points to 61.2 per cent in 2014.

Operating profit after tax rose 8 per cent for the year to US$429 million, in line with the underlying business growth.

Tan Hak Leh, chief executive of AIA Singapore, said the strong showing was attributable to the growth of the agency force, which is the largest in Singapore. The number of recruits grew 23 per cent compared with 2013, while the number of active agents rose by 16 per cent, he said.

The expansion of its agency force comes at a time when the web aggregator - which will allow consumers to compare general and life insurance products - is to be rolled out by the Monetary Authority of Singapore by the end of next month or so.

The introduction of the web aggregator paves the way for the sector to be digitised, and this has raised concerns that tied agents and financial advisers might be redundant.

However, Mr Tan said the majority of consumers still prefer personalised, face-to-face advice when it comes to purchasing life insurance products, so his agency force will be further strengthened in size and in competency to deliver quality advice.

The insurer also said its consumers like to search and compare products online. To build on its content strategy and digital marketing work, it has stepped up its search engine marketing and search optimisation.

Also a contributor to the company's growth is its bancassurance channel. Early last year, the insurer begun selling its products through Citibank's Asia-Pacific retail branch network.

AIA Group on Thursday announced a 22 per cent jump in full- year profit, led by business growth in China and Hong Kong. Net income rose to US$3.45 billion, or 28.73 US cents a share, in the 12 months through November, said the Hong Kong-based insurer in a statement to the stock exchange.

The value of new business leapt 24 per cent to US$1.85 billion, while its annualised new premiums went up 11 per cent to US$3.7 billion.

Operating profit after tax, which excludes US$508 million of net stock investment gains, rose 16 per cent year-on-year to US$2.91 billion.

The insurer, which traces its roots to Shanghai, raised its final dividend by 19 per cent to 34 Hong Kong cents a share, bringing full-year payout 18 per cent higher at 50 HK cents.

site_title: Malaysia to dish out more incentives for foreign investment
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Malaysia to dish out more incentives for foreign investment

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Malaysia

Follow

Kuala Lumpur

MALAYSIA will increase incentives for companies to relocate operations to the country as it seeks more foreign investments to bolster growth. Approved direct investments rose to a record 235.9 billion ringgit (S$89 billion) last year from 219.4 billion ringgit in 2013, International Trade and Industry Minister Mustapa Mohamed said in Kuala Lumpur Thursday. Domestic investments accounted for about 73 per cent of the total, he said.

Prime Minister Najib Razak is dismantling decades of subsidies and increasing his focus on luring foreign investment, boosting education standards and adding high-quality jobs to propel the economy into developed status by the end of this decade. The government is depending on the private sector to drive capital spending as it cuts operating expenditure to narrow a budget deficit.

"We are planning to introduce tax and location incentives for principal hub companies," Mr Mustapa told reporters. "These also include customized incentives." Mr Najib unveiled an Economic Transformation Programme in 2010 to attract US$444 billion of local and foreign private sector-led investment in Malaysia by 2020, ranging from oil storage to a subway in Kuala Lumpur.

Approved investments last year are projected to create more than 178,000 new jobs, Mr Mustapa said. So far, there are projects worth more than 65 billion ringgit in manufacturing and services that are waiting to be approved in 2015, he said.

The services industry accounted for about 63.4 per cent of approved investments in 2014, compared with about 30.5 per cent for manufacturing and 6.1 per cent for the primary sector. Malaysia is forecasting a budget shortfall of 3.2 per cent of gross domestic product in 2015, bigger than an October target of 3 per cent after a decline in crude prices curbed the oil producer's revenue. The country has reduced its dependence on oil for revenue to 29.7 per cent in 2014 from 35.4 per cent in 2010, Minister Idris Jala said in a separate statement Thursday. BLOOMBERG

site_title: Dismal start to 2015 for manufacturing
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Dismal start to 2015 for manufacturing

Q1 GDP growth could come in under 2%; some economists see higher risk of further MAS easing in April

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Singapore economy

Follow

Meagre rise

Singapore

IT was a slow and disappointing start to 2015 for Singapore's manufacturing sector, which grew less than expected in January despite an undemanding year-ago base. The surprisingly weak showing was due to a broad-based, uninspiring performance across all industrial clusters, save biomedical manufacturing and precision engineering.

Factory output rose just 0.9 per cent in January on a year-on-year basis, far lower than the market's consensus forecast of a 3.3 per cent increase. Strip out the volatile biomedical cluster, and the result would have been even worse: a zero-growth outcome with unchanged output.

With February's factory output expected to be weak on Chinese New Year plant closures, private-sector economists now say Q1 GDP growth is likely to come in under the government's 2015 GDP forecast range of 2-4 per cent.

Given how much the inflation outlook continues to be subdued - thanks in part to lower oil prices and new subsidies announced in Budget 2015 - at least one bank, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, thinks the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will ease policy further in April.

January's meagre rise in industrial production was thanks to the biomedical manufacturing cluster, which expanded 5.3 per cent - a turnaround from December's 1.2 per cent decline.

However, the 3.6 per cent growth in pharmaceuticals, coupled with a 4.1 per cent rise in precision engineering output, was not enough to offset contractions in the transport engineering (-2.2 per cent), chemicals (-0.5 per cent), and general manufacturing (-0.3 per cent) clusters.

Production in the key electronics cluster - which retains the largest weight of 33.4 per cent on the industrial production index - was unchanged in January.

Releasing the data on Thursday, the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) said that, after adjusting for seasonal factors, industrial production contracted 4.7 per cent month-on-month in January. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output would have fallen 4.6 per cent.

This was also worse than the 2.4 per cent decline private-sector economists had anticipated, according to an earlier Bloomberg poll.

Economists expressed surprise at January's lower-than-projected growth in industrial production; those from Barclays and Credit Suisse had been expecting some front-loading of production last month, ahead of plant closures in February due to the Chinese New Year festive season.

"But that didn't come through, and so the risk is probably that February will continue to be weak, based on the holiday effect. The broader point is that the first quarter is likely to be quite subdued for manufacturing, especially when compared to the fourth quarter (of 2014)," said Credit Suisse's Michael Wan.

He believes Q1 GDP could decline about 0.4-0.8 per cent quarter-on- quarter in annualised terms. This, he says, would imply year-on-year GDP growth of up to 1.6 per cent in Q1, down from 2.1 per cent in Q4 last year.

Bank of America Merrill Lynch economist Chua Hak Bin agrees that Q1 GDP growth will come under the official 2015 projection of 2-4 per cent. He also says that several Budget 2015 measures - medical and education subsidies, Service & Conservancy Charges rebates, and the deferment of foreign worker levies - could reduce inflation risks further.

Because of these factors, Dr Chua believes the central bank will ease monetary policy further at its April meeting - even after it surprised in January by reducing the slope of the S$NEER (Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate) policy band.

He said: "MAS will likely re-centre the band lower to the prevailing level of the S$NEER. We expect MAS to maintain the current weak appreciation bias. We are not expecting MAS to shift to a neutral bias (of zero appreciation) as such a move is more drastic and occurs largely only in recessions and crises. We are not expecting a recession, but we think there is a high probability that the government will have to reduce the GDP growth forecast to 1-3 per cent before midyear, from the current 2-4 per cent."

Dr Chua also told BT that "unless productivity growth really comes to the rescue", one per cent GDP growth per year "is probably a good number" in the longer term.

While Credit Suisse's Mr Wan now sees a higher risk of MAS easing, neither he nor economists from Citi or CIMB see this as their base case.

Said CIMB's Mr Song: "Monetary policy was recently revised, and I think MAS has taken all of these (inflation and growth) factors into consideration already. So I don't see any further easing especially after the last round - unless we have a further significant downshift in either growth or inflation."

SUBSCRIBERS

Hong Leong Finance warns SMEs of headwinds

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

hong leong finance

Follow

Hong Leong Finance

Singapore

HONG Leong Finance on Thursday warned of uncertainties and challenges among small and medium-enterprises amid the restructuring toll.

"Business models and processes have to change, thus creating new avenues of financing for small companies," Hong Leong said in its financial statement, as it reported a 10.4 per cent fall in full-year net profit after providing for doubtful debts.

Net profit for the year ended Dec 31, 2014 stood at S$62.8 million, compared to S$70.1 million a year ago. This translated to earnings per share of 14.17 Singapore cents, down from 15.85 Singapore cents a year ago.

"The decline in profit for 2014 when compared to 2013 is accentuated by the standard industry practice of immediately topping up general prudential provision when the loan book grew in 2014, ahead of the income generated from the increases in the loan portfolio," the company said.

This comes even as non-performing loans remain low, and are "substantially secured", Hong Leong said.

It set aside a S$2.02 million allowance for doubtful debts for the year. This compared against a writeback of S$2.34 million a year ago.

Net interest income inched up 0.5 per cent from a year ago to S$149 million. While pricing for lending products came under some pressure, this was mitigated by the overall growth in the total loan book, Hong Leong said. Net loan assets including hire purchase receivables rose 5.4 per cent to S$9.58 billion. But its fee and commission income fell 20.9 per cent to S$12.3 million. Costs were controlled, with staff costs - the biggest cost component - dipping 0.8 per cent from a year ago to S$61.7 million.

Hong Leong noted that the property market continues to be subdued, given the series of cooling measures.

"The motor vehicle market is likewise experiencing a steep downturn due to the current rules and regulations and in place," it added.

It proposed a final dividend of six Singapore cents per share.

Shares of Hong Leong closed on Thursday at S$2.67, up two Singapore cents.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew still sedated in ICU
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Lee Kuan Yew still sedated in ICU

91-year-old misses Tanjong Pagar Chinese New Year dinner for third straight year

Lee U-Wen

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 09:50 PM

Lee Kuan Yew

Follow

Singapore

FORMER prime minister Lee Kuan Yew is still in intensive care at the Singapore General Hospital (SGH), said the Prime Minister's Office (PMO) on Thursday in its latest update on the 91-year-old's health.

Mr Lee is in the hospital's Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and remains sedated. He is also using a ventilator to help him breathe. His doctors have restarted him on antibiotics and are continuing to monitor him closely, the statement added.

Mr Lee, a member of parliament for the Tanjong Pagar group representation constituency (GRC), was first admitted to SGH on Feb 5 for severe pneumonia.

On Saturday, the PMO had said that his condition was stable and that he was conscious and lightly sedated.

Mr Lee's extended illness meant that he had to miss his constituency's annual Chinese New Year dinner, on Thursday, for the third time in a row.

Last year, he skipped the function because he was hospitalised for an infection, fever and cough. And in 2013, he was admitted to SGH for a suspected episode of a transient ischaemic attack, a condition in which an irregular heartbeat leads to a brief stoppage of blood flow to the brain.

The other four MPs of Tanjong Pagar GRC - Social and Family Development Minister Chan Chun Sing, Senior Minister of State for Education and Law Indranee Rajah, and backbenchers Lily Neo and Chia Shi-Lu - attended Thursday's dinner held at the campus of Shelton College International in Telok Blangah.

The event, which attracted some 1,500 residents and grassroots leaders, was hosted by Sam Tan, the Minister of State at both the PMO and the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth. Mr Tan is the MP of the Radin Mas single ward, which neighbours Tanjong Pagar GRC.

As the guests streamed into the venue, most of them stopped to pen their well-wishes to Mr Lee on a large banner near the school's entrance.

In a speech delivered in both English and Mandarin, Mr Chan said that the best present that today's younger generation of grassroots leaders in Tanjong Pagar and Radin Mas could give to Mr Lee as he recovers in hospital would be to continue to take good care of the residents, especially the pioneers and the less-privileged.

Mr Chan, the newly appointed deputy secretary-general of the National Trades Union Congress, also gave his take on this year's Budget that was delivered by Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam in parliament earlier this week.

He said that it was "not a one-year Budget for a short-term gain", but rather one that charts the course for a long-term trajectory for Singapore to invest in its workers and companies.

"This year's Budget is not just about redistributing to help the poor. More importantly, it's an investment in the future, to set the foundation for us to compete in the future," he added.

"We will make sure that, year after year, we continue to enlarge the pie (so) that our workers have better salaries and better working conditions, and that our businesses can succeed not just in Singapore and the region, but in the global environment too."

site_title: Goldman employees reaped US$2b from 2008 options
content:
Goldman employees reaped US$2b from 2008 options

Published

Thu, Feb 26, 2015 · 11:28 AM

[NEW YORK] While Goldman Sachs Group Inc employees may get less compensation than in the past, many cashed in last year for a payday they've been awaiting since the depths of the financial crisis.

Employees exercised options worth US$2.03 billion in 2014. More than 96 per cent of the contracts were granted as part of 2008 compensation. Last year marked the first time bankers were able to take advantage of those awards.

Goldman Sachs's stock has more than doubled since it granted 36 million options in Dec 2008 to give top performers incentive to stay. The bank had been forced to slash compensation costs that year, as a global credit crisis endangered the firm and pushed its shares down 61 per cent.

The more-than US$2 billion total disclosed in a regulatory filing this week is the pretax gain from exercising the options. Recipients - who can choose to keep the stock or convert it to cash - may include former employees who left the New York-based company after receiving the options.

Current partners, who make up fewer than 2 per cent of the firm's 34,000 people, have accounted for an outsize portion of the payoffs. As of August, partners had reaped pretax gains of almost US$800 million from the 2008 options. The bank has yet to disclose their activity in the last four months of the year.

The investment bank's most senior leaders didn't receive the options, as Chief Executive Officer Lloyd C Blankfein and President Gary D Cohn took no bonus for 2008.

The options were granted at an exercise price of US$78.78 and vested over years. Another US$1.4 billion of the 2008 options were still outstanding at the end of 2014, when the stock closed at US$193.83.

Goldman Sachs has cut the portion of revenue it pays employees since the crisis as it seeks to boost returns amid higher capital requirements. Compensation costs were US$12.7 billion last year, down from a peak of US$20.2 billion in 2007. Since the 2008 options vested in previous years, their cost wouldn't have been included in last year's figure.

The firm said in the filing this week that it awarded restricted shares worth about US$2.5 billion as part of 2014 pay, up from US$2.3 billion a year earlier. It didn't award any options.
